dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the Sarajevo one? The spark for World War I? What about it?

dialogue_turns.text: Well, the author was on a museum tour, and they were talking about changing exhibits to let different countries show their relics. And he, uh, remarked that Princip's pistol is irreplaceable, you know?

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But the curator apparently replied that *three* Asian museums claim to have the authentic one on display. Three!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? That's... I mean, you can't have three authentic pistols for one event, right? Only one triggered the war.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? That's... I mean, you can't have three authentic pistols for one event, right? Only one triggered the war.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...only one pistol, not four, triggered the outbreak of World War I.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: My point exactly! The article's main takeaway is that you can't be "pluralistic and inclusive" when historical facts dictate a single right answer. Experts should decide, not, like, political agendas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: My point exactly! The article's main takeaway is that you can't be pluralistic and inclusive when historical facts dictate a single right answer. Experts should decide, not, like, political agendas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We cannot be pluralistic and inclusive when historical facts dictate a single right answer to a question. And such questions must be decided by experts who have been rigorously educated in the history (and trained in the historical sources) of a given era, not by those with a political agenda.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that makes total sense. And it really ties into the other point the article makes about how facts and science are, uh, under attack in Europe right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that makes total sense. And it really ties into the other point the article makes about how facts and science are, uh, under attack in Europe right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But scientists, their institutions, and the legitimacy of scientific knowledge itself are under increasing threat in several European countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! Governments blocking funding for research in Romania, removing entire educational programs in the Czech Republic, even eliminating disciplines in Slovakia! It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Governments blocking funding for research in Romania, removing entire educational programs in the Czech Republic, even eliminating disciplines in Slovakia! It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Freely elected governments have recently blocked financial support for research projects with no official explanation (Bulgaria), removed educational programs from the list of accredited university subjects (Hungary), and even eliminated entire disciplines (Poland).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's like they're just disregarding centuries of university tradition. Even during the communist era, some of that was respected, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And the article makes this really important point: these aren't ignorant people. Like, senior members of the Romanian government who, you know, forced CEU to move, had scholarships from Soros themselves!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And the article makes this really important point: these aren't ignorant people. Like, senior members of the Romanian government who, you know, forced C E U to move, had scholarships from Soros themselves!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Senior members of the Hungarian government that forced the Central European University, founded by the financier George Soros, to move to Vienna, and banned gender studies, had previously received scholarships from Soross Open Society Foundation to study in Oxford, New York, and elsewhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's not ignorance, it’s a deliberate agenda. They understand that knowledge is power, and they want the state to decide what's "necessary" research.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's not ignorance, it's a deliberate agenda. They understand that knowledge is power, and they want the state to decide what's necessary research.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These are highly educated people who know that knowledge is power, have a clear agenda, and are taking advantage of the fact that education in the European Union is the responsibility of national governments, not Brussels-based institutions. These governments want to establish an educational system according to which the state alone decides which fields of research are necessary and socially important.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And in the long run, they probably want to grant politically loyal people the right to produce and transfer knowledge. Access to knowledge stops being a civil right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And in the long run, they probably want to grant politically loyal people the right to produce and transfer knowledge. Access to knowledge stops being a civil right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the long run, they probably also want the state to grant political loyalists the right to produce and transfer knowledge. In other words, access to knowledge will cease to be a civil right.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, like, super anti-democratic. It's essentially putting experts in the service of anti-democratic goals, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, like, super anti-democratic. It's essentially putting experts in the service of anti-democratic goals, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would mean the de-democratization of higher education and of science in general and putting experts in the service of broader anti-democratic goals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Completely. We have to resist that. Access to science *is* a human right, and knowledge produced through democratic inquiry is inherently higher quality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Completely. We have to resist that. Access to science is a human right, and knowledge produced through democratic inquiry is inherently higher quality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To prevent the latter, we must resist the former. Democratic science policies build on the principle that access to science is a human right. Furthermore, they assume correctly that the knowledge produced through a democratic spirit of inquiry is of higher quality than that produced by someone who became an expert through political connections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and we can’t just let governments appoint their buddies as arbiters of truth. That's, um, a really dangerous path.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and we can't just let governments appoint their buddies as arbiters of truth. That's, um, a really dangerous path.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We must, therefore, fight the disturbing trend of European governments giving themselves the right to decide scientific questions, and appointing loyal supporters to act as arbiters of truth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So, defending the democratic quest for knowledge isn't just up to academics. It's for all of us, especially when they're trying to decide by government decree which pistol was fired in Sarajevo.
